III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff bit Youth C injuring his left upper forearm.
Investigation I notified Complainant and Youth C’s foster care worker that I
was assigned this complaint. Neither expressed any additional
concerns.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA) by phone on Monday
4/3/23 and requested the incident report, history of Staff 1’s
disciplinary write-ups and staff schedules. CA was unaware
Youth C had a bite mark on his arm. I instructed CA to check
Youth C’s arm and take him to urgent care immediately if there
2

was evidence of a human bite or other injuries needing medical
attention. Afterhours CA emailed that Youth C was taken to
urgent care.
I collaborated with Government Worker 1 who observed Youth C’s
arm on 4/3/23 within one hour of receiving the complaint and
forwarded photos of a red and purple circular bruise the size of a
tennis ball on his inner left arm that resembled a human bite mark.
Government Worker 1 informed me that CA arranged that Staff 1
would not be working with any children at the facility until this
investigation concludes.
I reviewed medical documentation from MedCare Urgent Care. It
indicated Youth C was examined on 4/3/23 at 5:47pm. and
diagnosed with Human bite of left forearm, Accidental bite by
another person, initial encounter. Antibiotics and topical ointment
were prescribed.
I reviewed the incident report noticing it indicated Youth C bit Staff
1 on his arm. I emailed CA and recommended that Staff 1 also be
seen by a medical professional. Afterhours on 4/4/23, CA
confirmed Staff 1 received medical attention for a human bite.
I interviewed Youth C, who turned age 18 on 4/4/23, jointly with
Government Worker 1 on 4/5/23. He claimed he did not
remember most of what happened on 4/1/23 due to short and
long-term memory problems.
Youth C said he takes six or seven pills per day and does not
know what the pills are for. According to Government Worker 1,
he is being treated for attention and mood disorders.
In terms of the allegation, Youth C said, “Staff 1 and 2 were there.
Youth N was awake in front of the cottage…I threw a book toward
Staff 2 or Staff 1. I don’t remember…I threw a weight thing behind
me. It hit the TV. The TV broke…I didn’t break any windows this
time…I tried to run out the door. Staff restrained me. They
pushed me on the ground…They fell. They held me on the
ground. I struggled. I don’t remember.” Asked about the large
circular mark on his left arm, Youth C said he was not sure if it
was a bite, or a bruise caused by the fall. He did not remember if
anyone bit him.
In addition to the bite mark, Youth C had multiple horizontal scabs
formed from self-inflicted superficial cuts on his inner arm. Asked
what he generally uses to cut himself, he replied casually,
3

“Whatever I find on the ground.” Youth C had extremely short
fingernails and scabs around his fingertips. Asked if he bites
himself, he affirmed, “I chew on myself a lot when I’m bored.”
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for 10 years. On 3/31/23, Staff 2 said he
started his shift in Juhnke cottage alone monitoring seven youth
during sleeping hours.
Staff 2 recalled the incident on 4/1/23. “I called Supervisor at
10pm because the kids were not going to bed and were annoying
Youth C. Youth C busted the window in his room, picked up glass
and cut his arm. It bled. Two youth ran (with permission) to get
Supervisor. (Staff 1 arrived) Youth C picked up a weight, hit the
TV and knocked out (another) window. Youth C threw the weight
at another (third) window. He banged the window, knocked it out
and climbed out the window. Youth C came back inside, tore off
the TV cover and tried to take the second TV down. He jumped
up to tear it down and fell on the floor. We (Staff 2 and 1) picked
him up. Supervisor arrived. Me and Supervisor escorted Youth C
outdoors. I noticed Youth C bleeding. He was escalated. I
verbally deescalated him. We went back in the cottage and Youth
C calmed down. I got peroxide, cleaned his bloody hands and
took off his shirt. I asked if there were any other injuries. He said,
‘No.’ At 4am, Staff 1 showed me a bite mark on his arm. He
(Staff 1) said Youth C bit him…I did not see Youth C bite him…I
did not see anyone bite Youth C.” The next morning Staff 2 said
he “checked in” with the youth and Youth C told him he was
“good.”
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for 15 years and was suspended on 4/3/23
until this investigation concludes. Government Worker 1 read the
allegation aloud. Staff 1 appeared puzzled.
On 4/1/23, Staff 1 arrived late to Juhnke Cottage due to being
relieved late in another cottage. When Staff 1 stepped into the
cottage, he said he witnessed the following:
“I saw Staff 2 talking to Youth C and broken glass; the window in
his room smashed. Youth C began destroying things; threw a
trash can, threw a weight toward me. Staff 2 tried to redirect. I
called Supervisor and asked him to call the cops. Youth C broke
another window and broke the TV in the playroom. He went to the
living room and broke a second TV. We redirected him. He went
toward the front door; smashed a third window and frame. We
4

were concerned for his safety. We tried to hold his arms to begin
a two-person restraint. We were unsuccessful. All three of us hit
the ground. Youth C began to sock me in my chest and face…
(There were no other kids present) I…got up. Youth C went
outdoors. I noticed I was bit on my (right lower outer) arm. Five
minutes later Youth C returned. I wrapped up my own arm. It was
bleeding. Youth C smiled. I told him he bit me. Youth C said he
has very sharp teeth. Youth C had cuts on his fingers. Staff 2 did
a body chart. Supervisor arrived at the cottage.”
Staff 1 continued, “About 11pm, four squad cars and eight police
officers came inside (Juhnke Cottage). They talked to Youth C
and shook their heads (at the damage). Youth C played his guitar
for the police. The police told me, “Good luck. You guys have a
tough job.”
Staff 1 said neither he nor Staff 2 ever bit Youth C. In fact, he said
Youth C never identified a human bite or any other injuries that
night aside from the cuts on his hands. “I looked at him; treated
him that night. There was nothing there. Youth C has a long
history of suicide attempts and biting himself,” he added.
I interviewed Youth N jointly with Government Worker 1. He said
Youth C broke three windows, two TVs, had glass and tried to cut
himself. Youth N said he took the glass from Youth C. Glass from
a window cut Youth N’s left inner wrist. Supervisor arrived. Youth
C calmed down and went outside. Youth N followed him and
encouraged Youth C apologize to staff and his peers for
destroying their means of entertainment. Four police cars and an
ambulance arrived. Youth N left in the ambulance to the hospital
and got stitches in his wrist at the hospital. In terms of Staff 1
biting Youth C, Youth N stated adamantly, “I was there. Staff 1
did not bite Youth C. He was not ever close enough to bite him.
No one bit him.”
I interviewed Youth T jointly with Government Worker 1. He said
he saw Youth C cut his arm with glass and run outside. Then the
police arrived. Youth T provided no additional information.
The incident report authored by Staff 1 dated 4/1/23 at 10:45pm
indicated Staff 1 saw Youth C leave his room after breaking his
bedroom window. Youth C threw a dumbbell toward staff, broke
two televisions, two more windows, and swung at and hit staff.
Staff held the youth’s arms to prevent further injury. Youth C
struggled. Staff released and the youth and staff fell to the floor.
Youth C bit Staff 1’s arm breaking the skin. Youth C calmed
5

down, smiled, and told Staff 1 “I have really sharp teeth.”
Supervisor was notified and contacted the Redford police. A body
chart showed fresh cuts on Youth C’s hands but no bite mark.
The report did not indicate that Staff 2 was present and involved,
that a two-person standing control hold was attempted but
unsuccessful, that police arrived at the scene and spoke with
Youth C, or that first aid was provided to Youth C. The body chart
did not show the old marks and scars already present on Youth
C’s his body prior to the incident.
CONSULTATION
When completing body charts, staff should include all marks
observed on the youth’s body including old marks and scars,
identifying them as such on the chart. I recommended adding a
staff signature line on the chart as well as the date and time the
chart was completed.
Before signing incident reports, supervisors should ensure the
report identifies all youth/staff involved, the type of restraint holds
or protective moves used (i.e., two-person standing control hold,
block), unsuccessful attempts to restrain, police arriving at the
scene, and any first aid provided by staff.
Analysis Staff 1 and 2 were in the cottage when Youth C began breaking
windows, cutting himself, destroying property, hitting staff, and
jeopardizing the safety of himself and others. To prevent further
injury, Staff 1 and 2 attempted a two-person standing restraint but
were unsuccessful. Youth C struggled and, in the momentum,
both staff and the youth fell to the floor. Staff 1 and 2 did not push
Youth C to the floor or hold him there.
During the incident Youth C bit Staff 1’s right arm. There was no
bite mark on Youth C’s body as evidenced by a body chart
completed by Staff 1. There were, however, self-inflicted cuts on
Youth C’s hands.
Staff 1 and 2 insisted Youth C never said anyone bit him and did
not complain of pain in his upper arm the night of the incident or
the next morning. It was not until two days later at school that
Youth C showed Complainant a bruise/bite mark on his arm. On
4/3/23, he told Complainant and Government Worker 1 that Staff 1
bit his arm. On 4/4/23 at urgent care, according to his diagnosis,
Youth C told medical professionals that he was bit “accidentally by
an unknown person.” Then on 4/5/23, Youth C told me and
6

Government Worker 1 he could not remember if or when anyone
actually bit him.
Staff 1 is a seasoned direct care worker with no disciplinary write-
ups in his file. All staff and youth who witnessed the event denied
that Staff 1 bit Youth C’s arm. Youth C, on the other hand, does
have a history of cutting, biting and chewing his own skin, and did
bite Staff 1’s arm.
Given the location of the bite mark (on the inside of Youth C’s
upper arm), along with his history of biting and chewing on his
own skin, inconsistent statements, and self-reported memory
problems, the source and time of the bite cannot be determined.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
